t: Habakkuk 3
Habakkuk’s Third Prayer
A*p prayer of the prophet Habakkuk. According to Shigionoth.
Lord,*spn I have heard the report about you; Lord,*sln I stand in awe of your deeds. Revive*ln your work in these years; make*ln it known in these years. In*ln your wrath remember mercy!
God*pn comes from Teman, the*ln Holy One from Mount Paran. Selah*ig His*ln splendor covers the heavens, and*ln the earth is full of his praise.
His*ln brilliance is like light; rays*ln are flashing from his hand. This*ln is where his power is hidden.
Plague*ln goes before him, and*ln pestilence follows in his steps.
He*ln stands and shakes the earth; he*ln looks and startles the nations. The*ln age-old mountains break apart; the*ln ancient hills sink down. His*ln pathways are ancient.
I*ln see the tents of Cushan in distress; the*ln tent curtains of the land of Midian tremble.
Are*ln you angry at the rivers, Lord?*s Is*ln your wrath against the rivers? Or*ln is your fury against the sea when*ln you ride on your horses, your*ln victorious chariot?
You*ln took the sheath from your bow; the*ln arrows are ready to be used with an oath. Selah*ig You*ln split the earth with rivers.
The*ln mountains see you and shudder; a*ln downpour of water sweeps by. The*ln deep roars with its voice and*ln lifts its waves high.
Sun*ln and moon stand still in their lofty residence, at*ln the flash of your flying arrows, at*ln the brightness of your shining spear.
You*ln march across the earth with indignation; you*ln trample down the nations in wrath.
You*ln come out to save your people, to*ln save your anointed. You*ln crush the leader of the house of the wicked and*ln strip him from foot to neck. Selah*ig
You*ln pierce his head with*ln his own spears; his*ln warriors storm out to scatter us, gloating*ln as if ready to secretly devour the weak.
You*ln tread the sea with your horses, stirring*ln up the vast water.
Habakkuk’s Confidence in God Expressed

I*pn heard, and I trembled within; my*ln lips quivered at the sound. Rottenness*ln entered my bones; I*ln trembled where I stood. Now*ln I must quietly wait for the day of distress to*ln come against the people invading us.

Though*ln the fig tree does not bud and*ln there is no fruit on the vines, though*ln the olive crop fails and*ln the fields produce no food, though*ln the flocks disappear from the pen and*ln there are no herds in the stalls,
yet*ln I will celebrate in the Lord;*s I*ln will rejoice in the God of my salvation!
The*ln Lord*s my Lord is my strength; he*ln makes my feet like those of a deer and*ln enables me to walk on mountain heights! For*p the choir director: on stringed instruments.
